datatype.name: UM-BBD Reaction
datatype.definition: The University of Minnesota Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database (UM-BBD) contains information on microbial biocatalytic reactions and biodegradation pathways for primarily xenobiotic, chemical compounds. The goal of the UM-BBD is to provide information on microbial enzyme-catalyzed reactions that are important for biotechnology. This collection refers to reaction information.

resource.dataInfo: Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database Mirror (Reaction) at ETH Zurich
Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database (Reaction) at University of Minnesota
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology, University of Minnesota, Minnesota

datatype.name: UM-BBD Enzyme
datatype.definition: The University of Minnesota Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database (UM-BBD) contains information on microbial biocatalytic reactions and biodegradation pathways for primarily xenobiotic, chemical compounds. The goal of the UM-BBD is to provide information on microbial enzyme-catalyzed reactions that are important for biotechnology. This collection refers to enzyme information.

resource.dataInfo: Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database Mirror (Enzyme) at ETH Zurich
Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database (Enzyme) at University of Minnesota
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology, University of Minnesota, Minnesota

datatype.name: UM-BBD Pathway
datatype.definition: The University of Minnesota Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database (UM-BBD) contains information on microbial biocatalytic reactions and biodegradation pathways for primarily xenobiotic, chemical compounds. The goal of the UM-BBD is to provide information on microbial enzyme-catalyzed reactions that are important for biotechnology. This collection refers to pathway information.

resource.dataInfo: Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database Mirror (Pathway) at ETH Zurich
Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database (Pathway) at University of Minnesota
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology, University of Minnesota, Minnesota

datatype.name: UM-BBD Biotransformation Rule
datatype.definition: The University of Minnesota Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database (UM-BBD) contains information on microbial biocatalytic reactions and biodegradation pathways for primarily xenobiotic, chemical compounds. The UM-BBD Pathway Prediction System (PPS) predicts microbial catabolic reactions using substructure searching, a rule-base, and atom-to-atom mapping. The PPS recognizes organic functional groups found in a compound and predicts transformations based on biotransformation rules. These rules are based on reactions found in the UM-BBD database. This collection references those rules.

resource.dataInfo: Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database Mirror (Biotransformation Rule) at ETH Zurich
Biocatalysis/Biodegradation Database Mirror (Biotransformation Rules) at University of Minnesota
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology, University of Minnesota, Minnesota

datatype.name: mirEX
datatype.definition: mirEX is a comprehensive platform for comparative analysis of primary microRNA expression data, storing RT–qPCR-based gene expression profile over seven development stages of Arabidopsis. It also provides RNA structural models, publicly available deep sequencing results and experimental procedure details. This collection provides profile information for a single microRNA over all development stages.

resource.dataInstitution: Institute of Molecular Biology, Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan

datatype.name: Dictybase EST
datatype.definition: The dictyBase database provides data on the model organism Dictyostelium discoideum and related species. It contains the complete genome sequence, ESTs, gene models and functional annotations. This collection references expressed sequence tag (EST) information.

resource.dataInstitution: Northwestern University Biomedical Informatics Center and Center for Genetic Medicine, Chicago, Illinois

datatype.name: IMGT HLA
datatype.definition: IMGT, the international ImMunoGeneTics project, is a collection of high-quality integrated databases specialising in Immunoglobulins, T cell receptors and the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) of all vertebrate species. IMGT/HLA is a database for sequences of the human MHC, referred to as HLA. It includes all the official sequences for the WHO Nomenclature Committee For Factors of the HLA System. This collection references allele information through the WHO nomenclature.

datatype.name: Flystock

synonyms.synonym: Bloomington Drosophila Stock Center at Indiana University

datatype.definition: The Bloomington Drosophila Stock Center collects, maintains and distributes Drosophila melanogaster strains for research.

resource.dataInstitution: BDSC, Department of Biology, Indiana University, Bloomington

datatype.name: OPM
datatype.definition: The Orientations of Proteins in Membranes (OPM) database provides spatial positions of membrane-bound peptides and proteins of known three-dimensional structure in the lipid bilayer, together with their structural classification, topology and intracellular localization.

resource.dataInstitution: Department of Medicinal Chemistry, College of Pharmacy, University of Michigan

restriction.statement: Based upon, and uses identifiers from, a subset of PDB entries.

datatype.name: Allergome
datatype.definition: Allergome is a repository of data related to all IgE-binding compounds. Its purpose is to collect a list of allergenic sources and molecules by using the widest selection criteria and sources.

resource.dataInstitution: Center for Clinical and Experimental Allergology, Rome

restriction.statement: Non-commercial license associated.

datatype.name: PomBase
datatype.definition: PomBase is a model organism database established to provide access to molecular data and biological information for the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe. It encompasses annotation of genomic sequence and features, comprehensive manual literature curation and genome-wide data sets.

resource.dataInstitution: Cambridge Systems Biology Centre, Department of Biochemistry, University of Cambridge

datatype.name: HPA
datatype.definition: The Human Protein Atlas (HPA) is a publicly available database with high-resolution images showing the spatial distribution of proteins in different normal and cancer human cell lines. Primary access to this collection is through Ensembl Gene identifiers.

resource.dataInfo: Human Protein Atlas at AlbaNova University
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Proteomics, School of Biotechnology, AlbaNova University Center, Stockholm

restriction.statement: May not be suitable for commercial use.

datatype.name: JAX Mice
datatype.definition: JAX Mice is a catalogue of mouse strains supplied by the Jackson Laboratory.

restriction.statement: free for non-commercial or personal use

datatype.name: uBio NameBank
datatype.definition: NameBank is a "biological name server" focused on storing names and objectively-derived nomenclatural attributes. NameBank is a repository for all recorded names including scientific names, vernacular (or common names), misspelled names, as well as ad-hoc nomenclatural labels that may have limited context.

resource.dataInfo: uBio NameBank at The Marine Biological Laboratory
resource.dataInstitution: Marine Biological Laboratory, Woods Hole, Massachusetts

datatype.name: YeTFasCo
datatype.definition: The Yeast Transcription Factor Specificity Compendium (YeTFasCO) is a database of transcription factor specificities for the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae in Position Frequency Matrix (PFM) or Position Weight Matrix (PWM) formats.

resource.dataInstitution: Department of Molecular Genetics, Terrence Donnelly Centre for Cellular and Biomolecular Research, University of Toronto, Toronto

datatype.name: TarBase
datatype.definition: TarBase stores microRNA (miRNA) information for miRNA–gene interactions, as well as miRNA- and gene-related facts to information specific to the interaction and the experimental validation methodologies used.

resource.dataInstitution: IMIS Institute, Athena Research Center, Athens

datatype.name: CharProt
datatype.definition: CharProt is a database of biochemically characterized proteins designed to support automated annotation pipelines. Entries are annotated with gene name, symbol and various controlled vocabulary terms, including Gene Ontology terms, Enzyme Commission number and TransportDB accession.

resource.dataInstitution: J Craig Venter institute, Rockville, Maryland

datatype.name: OMA Protein
datatype.definition: OMA (Orthologous MAtrix) is a database that identifies orthologs among publicly available, complete genome sequences. It identifies orthologous relationships which can be accessed either group-wise, where all group members are orthologous to all other group members, or on a sequence-centric basis, where for a given protein all its orthologs in all other species are displayed. This collection references individual protein records.

resource.dataInfo: OMA Protein through OMA browser at ETH Zurich

restriction.statement: Terms of service under a noncommercial license.

datatype.name: OMA Group
datatype.definition: OMA (Orthologous MAtrix) is a database that identifies orthologs among publicly available, complete genome sequences. It identifies orthologous relationships which can be accessed either group-wise, where all group members are orthologous to all other group members, or on a sequence-centric basis, where for a given protein all its orthologs in all other species are displayed. This collection references groupings of orthologs.

resource.dataInfo: OMA Group through OMA browser at ETH Zurich

restriction.statement: Terms of service under a noncommercial license.

datatype.name: NCBI Protein
datatype.definition: The Protein database is a collection of sequences from several sources, including translations from annotated coding regions in GenBank, RefSeq and TPA, as well as records from SwissProt, PIR, PRF, and PDB.

resource.dataInstitution: National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), NIH, Maryland

restriction.statement: This collection is an aggregation of a variety of data sources.

datatype.name: GenPept
datatype.definition: The GenPept database is a collection of sequences based on translations from annotated coding regions in GenBank.

resource.dataInstitution: National Center for Biotechnology Information, NIH, Maryland

restriction.statement: This collection is a subset of the information found in the NCBI protein database.

datatype.name: UniGene
datatype.definition: A UniGene entry is a set of transcript sequences that appear to come from the same transcription locus (gene or expressed pseudogene), together with information on protein similarities, gene expression, cDNA clone reagents, and genomic location.

restriction.statement: It is not possible to directly specify a cluster ID without providing an organism abbreviation.

datatype.name: BitterDB Receptor
datatype.definition: BitterDB is a database of compounds reported to taste bitter to humans. The compounds can be searched by name, chemical structure, similarity to other bitter compounds, association with a particular human bitter taste receptor, and so on. The database also contains information on mutations in bitter taste receptors that were shown to influence receptor activation by bitter compounds. The aim of BitterDB is to facilitate studying the chemical features associated with bitterness. This collection references receptors.

resource.dataInfo: BitterDB Receptor at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem
resource.dataInstitution: The Robert H Smith Faculty of Agriculture, Food and Environment, The Institute of Biochemistry, Food Science and Nutrition, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Rehovot

datatype.name: BitterDB Compound
datatype.definition: BitterDB is a database of compounds reported to taste bitter to humans. The compounds can be searched by name, chemical structure, similarity to other bitter compounds, association with a particular human bitter taste receptor, and so on. The database also contains information on mutations in bitter taste receptors that were shown to influence receptor activation by bitter compounds. The aim of BitterDB is to facilitate studying the chemical features associated with bitterness. This collection references compounds.

resource.dataInfo: BitterDB Compound at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem
resource.dataInstitution: The Robert H Smith Faculty of Agriculture, Food and Environment, The Institute of Biochemistry, Food Science and Nutrition, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Rehovot

datatype.name: BioProject
datatype.definition: BioProject provides an organizational framework to access metadata about research projects and the data from the projects that are deposited into different databases. It provides information about a project’s scope, material, objectives, funding source and general relevance categories.

resource.dataInfo: BioProject at DNA Data Bank of Japan
resource.dataInstitution: DNA Data Bank of Japan, Shizuoka

datatype.name: BioSample
datatype.definition: The BioSample Database stores information about biological samples used in molecular experiments, such as sequencing, gene expression or proteomics. It includes reference samples, such as cell lines, which are repeatedly used in experiments. Accession numbers for the reference samples will be exchanged with a similar database at NCBI.

datatype.name: PiroplasmaDB
datatype.definition: PiroplasmaDB is one of the databases that can be accessed through the EuPathDB (http://EuPathDB.org; formerly ApiDB) portal, covering eukaryotic pathogens of the genera Cryptosporidium, Giardia, Leishmania, Neospora, Plasmodium, Toxoplasma, Trichomonas and Trypanosoma. While each of these groups is supported by a taxon-specific database built upon the same infrastructure, the EuPathDB portal offers an entry point to all these resources, and the opportunity to leverage orthology for searches across genera.

resource.dataInstitution: Center for Tropical & Emerging Global Diseases, University of Georgia, Georgia

datatype.name: Unite
datatype.definition: UNITE is a fungal rDNA internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequence database. It focuses on high-quality ITS sequences generated from fruiting bodies collected and identified by experts and deposited in public herbaria. Entries may be supplemented with metadata on describing locality, habitat, soil, climate, and interacting taxa.

resource.dataInstitution: Institute of Botany, University of Tartu, Tartu

datatype.name: NCIm
datatype.definition: NCI Metathesaurus (NCIm) is a wide-ranging biomedical terminology database that covers most terminologies used by NCI for clinical care, translational and basic research, and public information and administrative activities. It integrates terms and definitions from different terminologies, including NCI Thesaurus, however the representation is not identical.

resource.dataInstitution: National Cancer Institute, Center for Bioinformatics, Maryland

restriction.statement: Some proprietary terminologies are included, with permission, and have restrictions on their use.

datatype.name: ProGlycProt
datatype.definition: ProGlycProt (Prokaryotic Glycoprotein) is a repository of bacterial and archaeal glycoproteins with at least one experimentally validated glycosite (glycosylated residue). Each entry in the database is fully cross-referenced and enriched with available published information about source organism, coding gene, protein, glycosites, glycosylation type, attached glycan, associated oligosaccharyl/glycosyl transferases (OSTs/GTs), supporting references, and applicable additional information.

resource.dataInstitution: Institute of Microbial Technology, Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), Chandigarh

datatype.name: PolBase
datatype.definition: Polbase is a database of DNA polymerases providing information on polymerase protein sequence, target DNA sequence, enzyme structure, sequence mutations and details on polymerase activity.

datatype.name: NucleaRDB
datatype.definition: NucleaRDB is an information system that stores heterogenous data on Nuclear Hormone Receptors (NHRs). It contains data on sequences, ligand binding constants and mutations for NHRs.

resource.dataInfo: NucleaRDB at Radboud University Nijmegen Medical Centre
resource.dataInstitution: CMBI, Radboud University Nijmegen Medical Centre, Dreijenplein, Wageningen

datatype.name: SUPFAM
datatype.definition: SUPERFAMILY provides structural, functional and evolutionary information for proteins from all completely sequenced genomes, and large sequence collections such as UniProt.

resource.dataInfo: SUPFAM at MRC and University of Bristol
resource.dataInstitution: MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, Cambridge

datatype.name: Rice Genome Annotation Project
datatype.definition: The objective of this project is to provide high quality annotation for the rice genome Oryza sativa spp japonica cv Nipponbare. All genes are annotated with functional annotation including expression data, gene ontologies, and tagged lines.

resource.dataInfo: Rice Genome Annotation Project at TIGR
resource.dataInstitution: The Institute for Genomic Research, Rockville, Maryland

datatype.name: PINA
datatype.definition: Protein Interaction Network Analysis (PINA) platform is an integrated platform for protein interaction network construction, filtering, analysis, visualization and management. It integrates protein-protein interaction data from six public curated databases and builds a complete, non-redundant protein interaction dataset for six model organisms.

resource.dataInfo: Protein Interaction Network Analysis (PINA) at Garvan Institute
resource.dataInstitution: Garvan Institute of Medical Research, Sydney

restriction.statement: Protein-protein interaction data from IntAct, MINT, BioGRID, DIP, HPRD, MIPS/MPact, and Protein annotations from UniProt, Ensembl, WormBase.

datatype.name: Tissue List
datatype.definition: The UniProt Tissue List is a controlled vocabulary of terms used to annotate biological tissues. It also contains cross-references to other ontologies where tissue types are specified.

resource.dataInfo: Tissue List at Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics

datatype.name: BacMap Biography
datatype.definition: BacMap is an electronic, interactive atlas of fully sequenced bacterial genomes. It contains labeled, zoomable and searchable chromosome maps for sequenced prokaryotic (archaebacterial and eubacterial) species. Each map can be zoomed to the level of individual genes and each gene is hyperlinked to a richly annotated gene card. All bacterial genome maps are supplemented with separate prophage genome maps as well as separate tRNA and rRNA maps. Each bacterial chromosome entry in BacMap contains graphs and tables on a variety of gene and protein statistics. Likewise, every bacterial species entry contains a bacterial 'biography' card, with taxonomic details, phenotypic details, textual descriptions and images. This collection references 'biography' information.

resource.dataInfo: BacMap Biography at University of Alberta
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Computing Science, Food and Nutritional Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton

datatype.name: HGNC Symbol
datatype.definition: The HGNC (HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee) provides an approved gene name and symbol (short-form abbreviation) for each known human gene. All approved symbols are stored in the HGNC database, and each symbol is unique. This collection refers to records using the HGNC symbol.

resource.dataInfo: HGNC Symbol at HUGO Genome Nomenclature Committee

restriction.statement: The main HGNC collection [MIR:00000080] should be used in preference as it has more robust identifiers.

datatype.name: PANTHER Pathway
datatype.definition: The PANTHER (Protein ANalysis THrough Evolutionary Relationships) Classification System is a resource that classifies genes by their functions, using published scientific experimental evidence and evolutionary relationships to predict function even in the absence of direct experimental evidence. The PANTHER Pathway collection references pathway information, primarily for signaling pathways, each with subfamilies and protein sequences mapped to individual pathway components.

resource.dataInstitution: Keck School of Medicine, University of Southern California

datatype.name: BioSharing
datatype.definition: The web-based BioSharing catalogues aim to centralize bioscience data policies, reporting standards and links to other related portals. This collection references bioinformatics data exchange standards, which includes 'Reporting Guidelines', Format Specifications and Terminologies.

resource.dataInstitution: Oxford e-Research Centre, University of Oxford, Oxford

datatype.name: FungiDB
datatype.definition: FungiDB is a genomic resource for fungal genomes. It contains contains genome sequence and annotation from several fungal classes, including the Ascomycota classes, Eurotiomycetes, Sordariomycetes, Saccharomycetes and the Basidiomycota orders, Pucciniomycetes and Tremellomycetes, and the basal 'Zygomycete' lineage Mucormycotina.

resource.dataInstitution: Department of Plant Pathology & Microbiology, University of California, Riverside, California

restriction.statement: Provides access to information from multiple fungal species.

datatype.name: DARC
datatype.definition: DARC (Database of Aligned Ribosomal Complexes) stores available cryo-EM (electron microscopy) data and atomic coordinates of ribosomal particles from the PDB, which are aligned within a common coordinate system. The aligned coordinate system simplifies direct visualization of conformational changes in the ribosome, such as subunit rotation and head-swiveling, as well as direct comparison of bound ligands, such as antibiotics or translation factors.

resource.dataInstitution: Gene Center and Department for Biochemistry and Center for integrated Protein Science Munich, University of Munich, Munich

datatype.name: DRSC
datatype.definition: The DRSC (Drosophila RNAi Screening Cente) tracks both production of reagents for RNA interference (RNAi) screening in Drosophila cells and RNAi screen results. It maintains a list of Drosophila gene names, identifiers, symbols and synonyms and provides information for cell-based or in vivo RNAi reagents, other types of reagents, screen results, etc. corresponding for a given gene.

resource.dataInstitution: Department of Genetics, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts

datatype.name: OriDB Schizosaccharomyces
datatype.definition: OriDB is a database of collated genome-wide mapping studies of confirmed and predicted replication origin sites in Saccharomyces cerevisiae and the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe. This collection references Schizosaccharomyces pombe.

resource.dataInfo: OriDB Schizosaccharomyces at University of Nottingham
resource.dataInstitution: Centre for Genetics and Genomics, The University of Nottingham, Queen's Medical Centre, Nottingham

datatype.name: OriDB Saccharomyces
datatype.definition: OriDB is a database of collated genome-wide mapping studies of confirmed and predicted replication origin sites in Saccharomyces cerevisiae and the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe. This collection references Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

resource.dataInfo: OriDB Saccharomyces at University of Nottingham
resource.dataInstitution: Centre for Genetics and Genomics, The University of Nottingham, Queen's Medical Centre, Nottingham

datatype.name: PSCDB
datatype.definition: The PSCDB (Protein Structural Change DataBase) collects information on the relationship between protein structural change upon ligand binding. Each entry page provides detailed information about this structural motion.

resource.dataInstitution: Graduate School of Information Science, Nagoya University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku

datatype.name: SCOP
datatype.definition: The SCOP (Structural Classification of Protein) database is a comprehensive ordering of all proteins of known structure according to their evolutionary, functional and structural relationships. The basic classification unit is the protein domain. Domains are hierarchically classified into species, proteins, families, superfamilies, folds, and classes.

resource.dataInstitution: MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, Centre for Protein Engineering, Hills Road, Cambridge

datatype.name: ENA
datatype.definition: The European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) captures and presents information relating to experimental workflows that are based around nucleotide sequencing. ENA is made up of a number of distinct databases that includes EMBL-Bank, the Sequence Read Archive (SRA) and the Trace Archive each with their own data formats and standards. This collection references Embl-Bank identifiers.

datatype.name: DOMMINO
datatype.definition: DOMMINO is a database of macromolecular interactions that includes the interactions between protein domains, interdomain linkers, N- and C-terminal regions and protein peptides.

resource.dataInstitution: Informatics Institute and Department of Computer Science and Bond Life Science Center, University of Missouri, Columbia

datatype.name: PANTHER Node
datatype.definition: The PANTHER (Protein ANalysis THrough Evolutionary Relationships) Classification System is a resource that classifies genes by their functions, using published scientific experimental evidence and evolutionary relationships to predict function even in the absence of direct experimental evidence. PANTHER tree is a key element of the PANTHER System to represent ‘all’ of the evolutionary events in the gene family. PANTHER nodes represent the evolutionary events, either speciation or duplication, within the tree. PANTHER is maintaining stable identifier for these nodes.

resource.dataInstitution: Keck School of Medicine, University of Southern California

datatype.name: Consensus CDS
datatype.definition: The Consensus CDS (CCDS) project is a collaborative effort to identify a core set of human and mouse protein coding regions that are consistently annotated and of high quality. The CCDS set is calculated following coordinated whole genome annotation updates carried out by the NCBI, WTSI, and Ensembl. The long term goal is to support convergence towards a standard set of gene annotations.

resource.dataInstitution: National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), NIH, Maryland

datatype.name: Locus Reference Genomic
datatype.definition: Locus Reference Genomic (LRG) provides identifiers to stable genomic DNA sequences for regions of the human genome, providing a recognized reference-sequence standard for reporting sequence variants. LRG is maintained by the NCBI and the European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI).

resource.dataInfo: Locus Reference Genomic at University of Leicester
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Genetics, University of Leicester, Leicester

datatype.name: HPRD
datatype.definition: The Human Protein Reference Database (HPRD) represents a centralized platform to visually depict and integrate information pertaining to domain architecture, post-translational modifications, interaction networks and disease association for each protein in the human proteome.

resource.dataInstitution: Institute of Bioinformatics, International Tech Park, Bangalore

restriction.statement: HPRD is free for non-commercial, where it may incur a license fee.

datatype.name: GXA Gene
datatype.definition: The Gene Expression Atlas (GXA) is a semantically enriched database of meta-analysis based summary statistics over a curated subset of ArrayExpress Archive, servicing queries for condition-specific gene expression patterns as well as broader exploratory searches for biologically interesting genes/samples. This collection references genes.

datatype.name: GXA Expt
datatype.definition: The Gene Expression Atlas (GXA) is a semantically enriched database of meta-analysis based summary statistics over a curated subset of ArrayExpress Archive, servicing queries for condition-specific gene expression patterns as well as broader exploratory searches for biologically interesting genes/samples. This collection references experiments.

restriction.statement: This collection is a curated subset of ArrayExpress [MIR:00000036].

datatype.name: MetaboLights
datatype.definition: MetaboLights is a database for Metabolomics experiments and derived information. The database is cross-species, cross-technique and covers metabolite structures and their reference spectra as well as their biological roles, locations and concentrations, and experimental data from metabolic experiments. This collection references individual metabolomics studies.

datatype.name: National Bibliography Number
datatype.definition: The National Bibliography Number (NBN), is a URN-based publication identifier system employed by a variety of national libraries such as those of Germany, the Netherlands and Switzerland. They are used to identify documents archived in national libraries, in their native format or language, and are typically used for documents which do not have a publisher-assigned identifier.

resource.dataInfo: NBN through URN Resolver at German National Library

datatype.name: ORCID
datatype.definition: ORCID (Open Researcher and Contributor ID) is an open, non-profit, community-based effort to create and maintain a registry of unique identifiers for individual researchers. ORCID records hold non-sensitive information such as name, email, organization name, and research activities.

datatype.name: InChI
datatype.definition: The IUPAC International Chemical Identifier (InChI) is a non-proprietary identifier for chemical substances that can be used in printed and electronic data sources. It is derived solely from a structural representation of that substance, such that a single compound always yields the same identifier.

resource.dataInstitution: National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland

restriction.statement: Identifiers are the structural representation of a substance.
Identifiers are not restricted to a specific data collection.

datatype.name: Wikipedia (En)
datatype.definition: Wikipedia is a multilingual, web-based, free-content encyclopedia project based on an openly editable model. It is written collaboratively by largely anonymous Internet volunteers who write without pay.

restriction.statement: Identifiers are formed of descriptive text, and may not be unique, in which case a disambiguation page is returned.

datatype.name: PhosphoPoint Kinase
datatype.definition: PhosphoPOINT is a database of the human kinase and phospho-protein interactome. It describes the interactions among kinases, their potential substrates and their interacting (phospho)-proteins. It also incorporates gene expression and uses gene ontology (GO) terms to annotate interactions. This collection references kinase information.

resource.dataInfo: PhosphoPoint Kinase at National Taiwan University
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, National Taiwan University

datatype.name: PhosphoPoint Phosphoprotein
datatype.definition: PhosphoPOINT is a database of the human kinase and phospho-protein interactome. It describes the interactions among kinases, their potential substrates and their interacting (phospho)-proteins. It also incorporates gene expression and uses gene ontology (GO) terms to annotate interactions. This collection references phosphoprotein information.

resource.dataInfo: PhosphoPoint Phosphoprotein at National Taiwan University
resource.dataInstitution: Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, National Taiwan University

datatype.name: InChIKey
datatype.definition: The IUPAC International Chemical Identifier (InChI, see MIR:00000383) is an identifier for chemical substances, and is derived solely from a structural representation of that substance. Since these can be quite unwieldly, particularly for web use, the InChIKey was developed. These are of a fixed length (25 character) and were created as a condensed, more web friendly, digital representation of the InChI.

restriction.statement: Identifiers are composed of non-standard characters and do not follow recommended practices.
Identifiers are not restricted to a specific data collection, and are applicable universally.

datatype.name: UniProt Isoform
datatype.definition: The UniProt Knowledgebase (UniProtKB) is a comprehensive resource for protein sequence and functional information with extensive cross-references to more than 120 external databases. This collection is a subset of UniProtKB, and provides a means to reference isoform information.

resource.dataInfo: UniProt Isoform through Universal Protein Resource
UniProt Isoform through Universal Protein Resource using Persistent URL system

restriction.statement: UniProt Isoform is a subset of the information available from a standard UniProt record.

tagDefinition.name: annotation
tagDefinition.definition: Descriptive text, usually added by an author or curator, that provides extra information that may be missing or not immediately evident.

tagDefinition.name: bibliography
tagDefinition.definition: A citation list which supports the information provided. This may include books, publications in journal, or URL links.

tagDefinition.name: chemical
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with this tag reference data pertaining to chemical compounds and substances.

tagDefinition.name: classification
tagDefinition.definition: A classification scheme which does not necessarily depict a relationship between different groups, but only between individuals within a group.

tagDefinition.name: clustering
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with this tag contain data which has been processed in such a way as to generate subsets (clusters) within which some trait should be shared.

tagDefinition.name: controlled vocabulary
tagDefinition.definition: Controlled vocabularies provide predefined and authorised terms for shared use by a community, providing a means to organise knowledge for subsequent processing.

tagDefinition.name: disease
tagDefinition.definition: A disease is an abnormal condition of an organism that impairs bodily functions and can be deadly. It is also defined as a way of the body harming itself in an abnormal way, associated with specific symptoms and signs. [wikipedia]

tagDefinition.name: disorder
tagDefinition.definition: The term "disorder" is often considered more value-neutral than the term "disease" [wikipedia]. Hence it may have no attributable signs or symptoms.

tagDefinition.name: DNA
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with this tag reference data pertaining to deoxyribonucleic acid.

tagDefinition.name: domain
tagDefinition.definition: A domain is a protein subsequence that forms a three-dimensional structure, and can provide specific catalytic or binding sites as found in enzymes or regulatory proteins. A specific domain may appear in a variety of evolutionarily related proteins.

tagDefinition.name: drug
tagDefinition.definition: A drug, broadly speaking, is any chemical substance that, when absorbed into the body of a living organism, alters normal bodily function [wikipedia].Toxins are included in this category.

tagDefinition.name: encyclopedia
tagDefinition.definition: A generic knowledge repository not restricted to a particular domain, and which is primarily used for reference purposes.

tagDefinition.name: enzyme
tagDefinition.definition: An enzyme is a biological catalyst of a chemical reaction. Most enzymes are proteins.

tagDefinition.name: eukaryotic
tagDefinition.definition: Data collection pertaining to eukaryotic cells, which are differentiated from prokaryotic cells by the presence of a nucleus. This group includes human, plant, and fungal cells.

tagDefinition.name: expression
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections associated with this tag pertain to the measurement of gene expression, often through the use of microarray techniques, and usually in quantitative fashion.

tagDefinition.name: gene
tagDefinition.definition: Genes are discrete subsequences of genomic DNA and correspond to a unit of inheritance [based on wikipedia]. A data collection tagged 'gene' should include gene information in addition to purely sequence-oriented data.

tagDefinition.name: genome
tagDefinition.definition: A genome is the full compliment of hereditary information (usually DNA) for a given organism, and includes coding and non-coding sequences where applicable. 'Genome' tagged data collections are those whose information is derived from genome level sequencing projects.

tagDefinition.name: human
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections labelled 'human' should contain human centric data.

tagDefinition.name: image library
tagDefinition.definition: A repository of static images or animations.

tagDefinition.name: immunogenetics
tagDefinition.definition: A branch of research focused upon the relationship between one's genetics and immune response.

tagDefinition.name: interaction
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections tagged 'interaction' should contain information relating to molecular interaction data, often protein-protein.

tagDefinition.name: kinetics
tagDefinition.definition: Kinetics is the study of rates of reactions or chemical processes. Data collections tagged 'kinetics' should provide information such as rate laws and rate constants.

tagDefinition.name: lipid
tagDefinition.definition: Data collection pertaining to lipids, which are lipophilic, naturally-occurring molecules.

tagDefinition.name: mammalian
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections labelled 'mammalian' should contain mammal centric data.

tagDefinition.name: mass_spectrometry
tagDefinition.definition: Mass spectrometry is an analytical technique that identifies the chemical composition of a compound or sample on the basis of the mass-to-charge ratio of charged particles. [Wikipedia]

tagDefinition.name: metabolite
tagDefinition.definition: Metabolites are the intermediates and products of metabolism. The term metabolite is usually restricted to small molecules. A primary metabolite is directly involved in normal growth, development, and reproduction. A secondary metabolite is not directly involved in those processes, but usually has an important ecological function. Examples include antibiotics and pigments.

tagDefinition.name: microarray
tagDefinition.definition: Microarray is a high-throughput technology often used to measure gene expression.

tagDefinition.name: microbial
tagDefinition.definition: Datatype relating to bacterial species

tagDefinition.name: model
tagDefinition.definition: Data collection pertaining to mathematical models, encoded in a form that allows their use in simulation software.

tagDefinition.name: neuroscience
tagDefinition.definition: Scientific study of the nervous system.

tagDefinition.name: nucleotide
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections tagged with 'nucleotide' refer to DNA and RNA molecules.

tagDefinition.name: ontology
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections tagged with 'ontology' reference those ontologies that are used in the life sciences.

tagDefinition.name: pathway
tagDefinition.definition: Series of sequential chemical reactions that are referred to collectively.

tagDefinition.name: pharmacogenomics
tagDefinition.definition: Pharmacogenomics is the branch of pharmacology which deals with the influence of genetic variation on drug response in patients by correlating gene expression or single-nucleotide polymorphisms with a drug's efficacy or toxicity. [wiki]

tagDefinition.name: phenotype
tagDefinition.definition: A phenotype is any observable characteristic of an organism, such as its morphology, development, biochemical or physiological properties, or behaviour [wikipedia].

tagDefinition.name: plant
tagDefinition.definition: Dataype type should be focused on plant species

tagDefinition.name: polysaccharide
tagDefinition.definition: Polysaccharides are polymeric carbohydrate structures, formed of repeating units (either mono- or di-saccharides) joined together by glycosidic bonds. These structures are often linear, but may contain various degrees of branching. Polysaccharides are often quite heterogeneous, containing slight modifications of the repeating unit. [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polysaccharide]

tagDefinition.name: protein
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with this tag reference data pertaining to proteins.

tagDefinition.name: reaction
tagDefinition.definition: A single chemical reaction which yields products which are, generally, different from the reactants. Data collections tagged 'reaction' focus on individual chemical reactions.

tagDefinition.name: registry
tagDefinition.definition: A data collection within which information is registered or collated, effectively providing a catalogue for (community) reference purposes.

tagDefinition.name: sequence
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections tagged 'sequence' reference sequence data, such as DNA, RNA or protein.

tagDefinition.name: strain
tagDefinition.definition: A genetic variant of a particular organism.

tagDefinition.name: structure
tagDefinition.definition: Data collections with the 'structure' tag should reference chemical or 3-dimensional structure.

tagDefinition.name: taxonomy
tagDefinition.definition: A classification scheme, arranged in a hierarchical structure, that depicts parent-child relationships between its members.
